monogr.title: The theatre of the empire of Great Britaine : presenting an exact geography of the kingdomes of England, Scotland, Ireland, and the iles adioyning: with the shires, hundreds, cities and shire-townes, within ye kingdome of England, divided and described by Iohn Speed
monogr.author: Speed, John
monogr.extent: 14, 146, that is 280, 10 pages, illustrations (woodcuts), maps (metal cuts), 2°

keywords.term: Travel, topography, maps and navigational manuals

div.head: To the right well deseruing Mr. IOHN SPEED the Author of this worke.

lg.l: IN this BOOKE, (Bibliothec, or Booke of Bookes;
TIMES Library, PLACES Geographie)
All that is shewne for which the curious lookes
Touching this LAND, for Place, or Historie.
In which, thou hast with paine, with care, and skill,
Surueid this Land more neere then ere it was:
For which, thy Wit thou strain'd hast to thy Will,
That wils as much as Witte can bring to passe.
The faire Hibernia that Westerne Isle likewise,
In euery Member, Artire, Nerue, and Veine,
Thou by thine Arte dost so Anatomize,
That all may see each parcell without trauell.paine.
Heere Time, and Place, like friendly foes doe warre
Which should shew most desir'd Particulars;
But Place giues place, sith Time is greater farre;
Yet Place, well rang'd, gets glory by these warres.
No helps thou hadst, nor no assisting aide
In this attempt: but, Vertue gaue thee might
That well to doe, that well thou hast assaide
Which shall (in grace) out-liue immortall spight.
Hadst thou among the Romanes liu'd when they
Did signiorize the World; A Signiory
Should then (at least) haue guerdon'd thy Suruey,
Thy Mappes, Descriptions, and thine Historie.
But, thou dost liue when all Arts saue the Adulation.eight
(Illiberall▪liberall Arte) a begging goe;
That Arte alone, with her true friend Deceipt,
Gets all; then all seekes but that Arte to know.
But, by thy Arte though nought be purchased
But emptie Fame (that feeds, but fattens not)
Yet shall it feed thy NAME till D • ATH be dead▪
While emptie noble Names away shall rot.
The Leaues this Booke contains, and Maps here grau'n,
Are still as Feathers to thy Fames faire Wings,
To fanne fresh Aire vpon the face of Heauen;
And, raise the same aboue all ending Things:
That when Confusion wracks this double FRAME,
A Spirit shall moue on CHAOS Call'd thy Fame

closer.signed: The vnfained louer of thy person, IO. DAVIES
